components.html:
Why Study Newton Scooters?


YOUR GOAL is to build a scooter that can go farther than the Master Scooter pictured below. Your scooter should look exactly like the one below except for ONE change that you think will improve the scooter's performance.


In this unit, you will design, build, and test a scooter. We will show you how to make a better scooter by thinking about energy, where it comes from and where it goes.


Master Scooter

Your Ideas About How Newton Scooters Work

 

Watch a video of a rubber band car!

 

Here are some other examples of Newton Scooters

 

A rubber band car is a type of Newton Scooter. With materials right in your own home, you can build a Newton Scooter!
Write down your best ideas about what might affect how far a Newton Scooter will travel.

components.prompt: What are some factors that are important for a scooter to move?

components.html:
How Do Newton Scooters Work?



When you test your scooter you want it to go far. To help you think about the decisions you make as you design the scooter, we are going to investigate how the energy in the situation impacts the distance your scooter travels.

Conservation of Energy



Energy is not created or destroyed, which means it is conserved. Even though energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can be transformed.
There are 3 types of energy: potential energy, kinetic energy, and thermal energy. Let's explore how each of these affects your scooter!

Press "Use Ramp" or "Use Spring" to test the car using a ramp and a spring.
How can you make the scooter travel the greatest distance?

Testing a Newton Scooter

Press "Use Ramp" or "Use Spring" to test the car using a ramp and a spring. Be sure to watch the position-time graph form once you release the lever.

How can you make the scooter travel the greatest distance?

components.prompt: What was the farthest distance recorded with this scooter?
What changes in the spring and what position on the ramp make the car travel the farthest?

choices.text: Squeezing the spring more and placing the car at the bottom of the ramp
Squeezing the spring more and placing the car at the top of the ramp
Squeezing the spring less and placing the car at the bottom of the ramp
Squeezing the spring less and placing the car at the top of the ramp

components.prompt: Explain how the energy from the spring and the energy from the ramp are the same.

components.html:
Potential Energy

 

Both the car on the ramp and the car with the spring have energy that is stored and available to do a task. We call this type of energy potential energy.

Other objects, like a bow and arrow, can also store potential energy.

 

Ramp Car Spring Car Archer

components.prompt: How can you maximize the potential energy for the spring car?

choices.text: Let the spring be loose.
Squeeze the spring just a little.
Squeeze the spring half way so that it's not too tight.
Squeeze the spring all the way.

components.prompt: How can you maximize the potential energy for the ramp car?

choices.text: Leave the car at the bottom of the ramp.
Place the car on the ramp but near the bottom.
Place the car halfway up the ramp.
Place the car at the top of the ramp.

components.prompt: Look at the archer. How does his bow and arrow store potential energy?

choices.text: It stores potential energy when the arrow is pulled back on the bow.
It stores potential energy after the archer releases the arrow.
It stores potential energy only when the arrow is moving.
The bow and arrow cannot store potential energy.

components.prompt: What else can store potential energy like a bow and arrow. Explain. (Hint: Think of something that stretches.)

components.html:
Vary potential energy for the car and show how it changes how far the car goes.
Complete at least 3 trials and enter your data in the table below.

How are potential energy and distance related?

Use the simulation to explore the relationship between potential energy and distance.

components.prompt: How does the spring vary potential energy for the car?

choices.text: The spring increases potential energy for the car after it is released.
The spring increases potential energy for the car before it is released.
The spring decreases potential energy for the car before it is released.

components.prompt: Use evidence from the trials to explain how potential energy affects how far the car goes.

components.html:
Vary potential energy for the car and show how it changes how far the car goes.
Enter the highest levels for potential energy for each trial below.

What happens to potential energy?

This simulation shows what happens to potential energy to make the car move.

Use the simulation to explore how potential energy is transformed.

components.prompt: When the car is moving what kind of energy is it using?

choices.text: Kinetic
Potential
Thermal

components.prompt: How does potential energy affect how far the car travels?

choices.text: The less potential energy the farther the car travels.
The more potential energy the farther the car travels.
The more potential energy the less the car travels.
Potential energy does not affect how the car travels.

components.prompt: Using evidence from the trials, explain what happens to the car's potential energy.

choices.text: It transforms.
It stays the same.
It is destroyed.
It goes away.

components.prompt: Explain your choice.

components.html:
Converting Potential Energy to Kinetic Energy

Kinetic energy is MOVEMENT energy. When the car is moving, it has kinetic energy.

When the car starts moving, potential energy becomes kinetic energy.

components.prompt: When is potential energy turned into kinetic energy in the bow and arrow?

choices.text: When the bow and arrow are on the ground.
When the arrow is pulled back.
When the arrow is released from the bow.
When the arrow is traveling through the air.

components.prompt: What else can change potential energy into kinetic energy like the bow and arrow? Explain. (Hint: Think back to the object that stretches.)
A car moving down a ramp and an arrow just released from a bow don't keep moving forever. What do you think happens to the kinetic energy?

choices.text: It transforms.
It stays the same.
It is destroyed.
It goes away.

nodes.title: Where is the wheel and axle?

components.html:
Where is the axle?

In the next simulation you will be able to adjust the friction between the axle and the car body.

The axle is the rod that passes through the wheels.

nodes.title: What else happens to the scooter's energy?

components.html:
Vary body shape for the car and show how it changes how far the car goes.
Enter the highest values for each type of energy below.

What else affects how far a car moves?

Use the simulation to explore how body shape and body-axle friction affect how far the car travels.

components.prompt: Vary axle-body friction for the car and show how it changes how far the car goes. (Enter the highest values for each type of energy below.)
How does thermal energy affect how far the car travels?

choices.text: The more thermal energy the farther the car travels.
The less thermal energy the less the car travels.
The less thermal energy the farther the car travels.
Thermal energy does not affect how the car travels.

components.prompt: Which variable had the largest affect on how far the spring car travelled? Use evidence from the trials to support your answer.

components.html:
Converting Kinetic Energy into Thermal Energy

 

When two objects rub against each other there is friction. Friction creates heat. This heat is called thermal energy.

When there is friction while the car is moving, kinetic energy becomes thermal energy.

Spring Car Energy Graph

components.prompt: What would happen if the spring was squeezed all the way and released, but the car had no friction?

choices.text: The car would never stop moving.
The car would move for a while but would eventually stop.
The car would not move from its starting position.

components.prompt: Give another example of something that transfers kinetic energy into thermal energy as it moves. Explain how this transfer of energy affects how the object(s) move.
Which of the following explains how energy transforms (->) in the scooter:

choices.text: Potential Energy -> Kinetic Energy -> Thermal Energy
Potential Energy -> Thermal Energy -> Kinetic Energy
Thermal Energy -> Potential Energy -> Kinetic Energy
Kinetic Energy -> Thermal Energy -> Potential Energy

nodes.title: Law of the Conservation of Energy

components.html:
Law of the Conservation of Energy

Potential Energy + Kinetic Energy + Thermal Energy = Total Energy

Energy is not lost or created. It is either stored or transformed. This is called the law of the conservation of energy.

components.prompt:
Let's test the law of the conservation of energy. Using the energy graph, record the energy values for potential energy, kinetic energy, and thermal energy at 3 time points: 0 seconds, 5 seconds, and 15 seconds.

Add potential energy, kinetic energy, and thermal energy to calculate the total energy.
Using evidence from the table, how does the graph show the law of the conservation of energy?

components.html:
The Master Scooter Races!

 

Now that we know about how energy is stored and how it creates movement, let's find out how the Master Scooter performed.

The scooter's best distance is the distance you will need to beat!

The Master Scooter Races!

 

Below are the graphs of 2 Master Scooter test runs.

 

Test 1 Test 2

components.prompt: Something unexpected happened during Test 1. Use the graph to help you figure out what happened.

choices.text: The Master Scooter made it to the top of the hill but couldn't make it down.
The Master Scooter never moved.
The Master Scooter travelled 15 meters!
The Master Scooter hit a rock and travelled backward before stopping.

components.prompt: The Master Scooter had its best run during Test 2. How far did the Master Scooter travel?

components.html:
What question do you want to investigate?


Your challenge is to beat the Master Scooter's best distance: 1.8 m.


You will be investigating ONE variable to make your scooter different than the Master Scooter. Below are some ideas you can investigate or you can pick one of your own.

  • How will your scooter store potential energy?
  • How much friction is between the axle and the scooter body?
  • What shape is the scooter body?
  • Is there another factor you think would make your scooter go a farther distance?

Design Your Own Newton Scooter!

Now choose the variable you think will help your scooter to beat the Master!

Your scooter should look exactly like the scooter below except for the variable you choose to test.

components.prompt: What variable would your group like to test?

choices.text: potential energy source
friction between the wheels and axles
scooter body size
other (be sure to say which variable you choose in the box below)

components.prompt: How will the variable you change make your scooter different than the Master Scooter?
Why do you think your change will make your scooter better than the Master Scooter?

Use the stamp tool to start designing your Newtoon Scooter.

You can draw new materials with the other tools.

Be sure to label all of the important parts.

Below are the materials used to make the Master Scooter. Update the "Your Scooter" and "#" columns with the materials you plan to use to build your scooter.

We will provide tape, glue, skewers, rubber bands, and straws.
Remember: you are only changing ONE variable. What item is different between your scooter and the Master Scooter?

components.html:
Start Building Your Newton Scooter!


Now that you've designed your Newton Scooter, it's time to build it! Gather all of your materials and start building!

Use the guidelines worksheet and the Master Scooter to help you build your scooter.

components.prompt:
Testing Your Scooter

How do you think your scooter will perform?

Predict your scooter's performance on the graph below.
components.title: Your Scooter

components.html: Predict Your Scooter's Performance

components.prompt: What type(s) of energy will be affected by the variable you changed?

choices.text: Potential Energy
Kinetic Energy
Thermal Energy

components.prompt: Explain your choice. Be sure to describe how the lines in the graph above will change.

components.html:
Test Your Newton Scooter! 

Can you beat the Master?


There are 3 jobs during testing:


  1. The Tester will increase the potential energy of the scooter and then release it.
  2. The Time Keeper will take a timer and time how long your scooter travels. This person will announce each second for 5 seconds.
  3. The Marker will place a marker on the ground to mark the scooter's location at each second.

Once you have 3 people and everyone has a job, bring your scooter and a computer to a testing station.

GRAPH YOUR DATA

The motion sensor software allows you to export data as a "csv" file. Talk to your teacher about how to do this. When this file is on your computer, pick your best run and click Import Data below and select the file. When you see the graph answer the questions below.

components.prompt: How does your scooter compare to the Master Scooter? Use evidence from the graphs to support your answer.
Record how far your scooter has travelled at each time point.
Pick your best trial and graph your data below.
components.title: My Best Trial

components.prompt: What was the farthest distance your scooter travelled?
How does your scooter compare to the Master Scooter? Use evidence from the graphs to support your answer.

nodes.title: How did your scooter compare to your prediction?

components.html: Below is your prediction graph and the graph of your scooter. Think about how they compare.

components.prompt: How did your scooter compare to your prediction?

components.html:
What other types of energy can we test?

 

Testing the whole scooter gives us some information, but we can still learn more.

By using a ramp we can test the friction of your scooter. No need to wind up your rubber band or blow up a balloon, your scooter is only going to use gravity as a power source this time.

components.prompt: You will be comparing your scooter's performance to the Master Scooter's performance on the ramp. What type(s) of energy are you comparing with the set-up above?

choices.text: potential energy
kinetic energy
thermal energy

components.prompt:
Use the ramp to test out how far your car can move without the elastic power source.
  1. Place your scooter at the top of the ramp and let it slide down.
  2. Measure the distance from the bottom of the platform to where your scooter stops (at the rear wheels).

What is your friction score? Based on how far your scooter traveled, find your score below.

1: 200 cm and above (low friction)
2: 100-199 cm (medium friction)
3: 0-99cm (high friction)
Using evidence from the table, how does your scooter's friction differ from the Master Scooter's friction?

nodes.title: Take a picture and critique your Newton Scooter

components.prompt:
1. Take a picture of your Newton Scooter and upload it here.

2. In the box that says "Share with class", post your answers to these 2 questions (you can use responses you put in your notebook):

  1. Did your scooter perform better than the Master Scooter?
  2. What evidence do you have to support your response to question 1?

3. Press POST!

4. Take a look at other groups' responses to see who beat the Master's distance!
Based on the evidence, what could you change about your scooter to improve its performance?

choices.text: energy source
friction between the wheel and axle
size of the scooter body
other variable (be sure to mention what variable below)

components.prompt: Explain how changing the variable(s) you chose above will improve a scooter's performance.

components.prompt: Based on the variable you tested, what type of energy did you expect to affect?

choices.text: potential energy
kinetic energy

components.html: Improvements

components.prompt: If you were able to re-build your scooter, what changes would you make?
How would these changes make your scooter better?
With the time you have left, use the draw tools to make your dream scooter. How would you design a scooter to go as far as possible? What would it look like?
